label: Letter from William Heath to Nathanael Green
description: Letter from William Heath to Nathanael Green regarding his opinions on two questions which Major General Greene has posed: whether he has the right to command and the justification of an officer complaining of injuries sustained while in military capacity.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from William Heath to Nathanael Green regarding his opinions on two questions which Major General Greene has posed: whether he has the right to command and the justification of an officer complaining of injuries sustained while in military capacity.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information contact The Charleston Museum, 360 Meeting Street, Charleston, SC 29403.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 ppi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival Masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[William Heath to Nathanael Greene 
August 19, 1779
[RvW Box 1 Folder 10; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Mandeville August 19, 1779 –
Dear Sir,
I am honor'd with your favor of yesterday, in which
you express a wish to have my sentiments on two
points. First whether your right to command in
consequence of your rank is not unquestionable
and secondly whether any officer upon just military
principles will have reason to complain of an injury
from your exercising command in time of action
agreable [sic] to your rank.
With respect to the first, I am
fully of opinion that you have an unquestionable
right to command. And, with respect to the
second that no officer will have just reason to com-
-plain of injury being done to himself or y.e public, in
consequence of your exercising command in time
of action, agreable to your rank, provided the great
duties of your other department does not suffer, and
I conceive it very possible for you to discharge the
duties of both, since what is principally expected
from an officer of your rank is a superintendency [sic]
of the department, and not the execution of the
minutia of it. I have the honor to be, with
respect and esteem,        Dear Sir
Your obedient Servt.
W [William] Heath
Major Gen Greene
[End Page 1]
[Addressed:]
Major General Greene
West Point
[seal]
[Endorsed: upside down]
From Genl. [General] Heath
19th. Augt. [1] 779
[End Page 2]
